review_title: The review is only about the fundraising team, not all of MSF (as is the rating)
pros: Working for Médecins Sans Frontières is great
cons:
Here is a comparaison of what they offer and what is really happening
a) "Full training and ongoing coaching ", You'll get no training at all, they pretend to give you a day training at the beginning. But it's made by someone who has no idea what she's doing herself. You'll learn absolutely nothing.
b)"£10.55-14ph, guaranteed[...]" Wrong, you'll be paid 10.55, don't even try to ask for more.
c)"[...]raising awareness[...]" they don't care about that, they want you to hit target or you'll get fired
d)"£10 per day travel allowance" that I'll double with their promess to never send you further than 30min travel from your home. In reality, on average the travel is 3 hours a day and cost 17 pounds.
e)"Regular socials with your team" there were quite a few socials actually, but it was organized by the fundraisers, never by the management.
f) [...] progression [...] Probably the biggest lie. The management will do their best to not let you meet people from MSF (you'll almost never go to the headquarter, and when you have to, they'll try to make you leave as fast as possible). 

On top of that you can add the harrassment on new people. Putting pressure, using sentence like "you cost us money and you're useless." on their first week.

The location they send us to are dangerous and not made for fundraising. They won't change them even after a lot of complains from the team. They'll put the fault on the fundraisers.

They also offer 3 times a week an opportunity to give anonymous feedback. Unfortunately that feedback is received by the management directly and they then try to find who send it, which is not acceptable for a feedback that was supposed to be anonymous.
